text.author: Roy Greenslade
text.description: One of Italy's top television news readers, Maria Luisa Busi, has resigned from a state-funded TV channel saying that its coverage is biased in favour of prime minister Silvio Berlusconi
text.title: Roy Greenslade: Italian news reader quits in protest at Berlusconi

main.p: One of Italy's top television news readers, Maria Luisa Busi, has resigned from a state-funded TV channel saying that its coverage is biased in favour of prime minister Silvio Berlusconi.

Busi, left, is reported to have informed her bosses at Rai 1 of her feelings by pinning a candid letter of explanation on a notice board. Her departure at the weekend follows a series of clashes with the editor of the flagship evening TG1 news programme, Augusto Minzolini, who was selected for the job by Berlusconi.
She has plenty of support. Rai's president, Paolo Garimberti, said her decision was "another worrying signal of a situation that requires maximum attention from the company's top management."

In addition to controlling three of Italy's seven terrestrial TV channels as part of his Mediaset empire, Berlusconi exercises considerable influence on senior appointments at Rai through his position as premier.

Busi did not restrict her complaints to political bias. She also claimed the programme's content has been dumbed down, with too much emphasis on "theft-proof underpants" and not enough reporting on failing schools and hospitals.
